The menu is very well priced.  A date with a partner usually ends up being around $50 plus tip if you get drinks, apps, and entrees.  If you don't overdo it, like I usually do, you could easily spend much less and still  be just as happy.
author: Jesse M.

description:
The seafood here was very good.  I would've never known that a restaurant like this would be able to have such great seafood.  The area...........well......you know............it's not the greatest location in the city but if you are in the neighborhood.....it's good.

There are only a handful of Thai restaurants in the City that has a full bar.  Osha Thai on 2nd and 3rd, Ko So mui, Cha am, King of Thai on Grant ave, and now this place.

I didn't try the usual fare of pad thai, pad seew, or any of the curries this time.  I know......weird.  Came here for a birthday party so we had a preset family style menu.  The fried fish was fantastic, the tom yum soup with fresh seafood was awesome, chicken satay was eh, Thai salad was good, steak was good (don't know if this was on the menu or was it a special they made specifically for us).

The bar..............It's a crazy place when you have the owners Simon and Vincent drinking with you.  I'll just leave it at that.
author: jason g.

description:
The service here is appalling.

I really don't like the idea of posting a bad review, but the protocol here sickened me.

I popped in here for a quick drink while I waited for my friend who was running a bit late. I ordered a vodka soda - the bartendress didn't ask me what kind of vodka I wanted - didn't say a word to me, actually - and immediately grabbed the rail. I did want Absolut Citron, but I'm not one to cause a fuss, so I accepted the drink, paid the $7 (plus $1 tip), and took a sip.

The drink was awful. 

Way too strong, and the vodka was warm. Instead of bothering the now-busy waitress (like I said, I am loathe to give bad reviews), I decided some water to chase the mixed drink would solve the problem. I asked the closest employee (some Asian dude) if I could have a sip of water. He said nothing, scowled a little, and then grabbed a plastic cup, flipped on the tap, filled it up, and shoved it toward me. Then he said, "One dollar." 

?!?!?!? 

One fucking dollar? For tap water to wash down your shitty drink?? (He clearly knew I was a paying customer.) I asked him if he was joking and he just glared at me. So I told him I didn't want it anymore. He gave me another dirty look, dumped the tap water down the sink, and returned the plastic cup to its place atop the tower of plastic cups.

Needless to say - I will never come back here, or brake if I see that guy crossing the street.
author: Stephannie N.

description: Is thai food supposed to taste super sweet like dessert? I don't think so. The food here is pricey, disgustingly sweet, and the portions .  The happy hour isn't very happy, especially when three wings cost $4.  I only come here for thai iced tea now, and even that is way more expensive than it should be, but its right across the street from where I live so I guess I'm paying for convenience rather than quality.
author: Le T.

description:
A few of my girlfriends and I met up here to eat before a surprise! What was the surprise? --Wicked at the Orpheum Theater! =) 
This restaurant is a perfect place to grab a bite to eat before the show because it is within walking distance to the theater...the night was perfect! 

I didn't mean to judge a book by its cover, but the area outside is kinda ghetto, but that's SF for you...it IS in the TL! Anyway,I was pleasantly surprised when I walked into the restaurant. It was big, clean and there is a big bar at the entrance. The food was great! 

We had the fish cakes with cucumber salad, pad see eu, a chicken curry dish and a flavorful salad (sorry forgot what kind!)
The waitress gave us a complimentary dessert that was SO yummy! It was a warm milky dessert with jello balls or something. Similar to the Filipino dessert ginataan...

Service was great, food was great....all smiles here! 

By the way, WICKED was great!!! Dinner and the show was a perfect combo for a relaxing night out!
author: Jackilyn B.

description: Pleasant setting, polite service, reasonable prices, but the food - beef with peanut sauce - was bland and unimaginative.
author: Robert S.

description:
The Pad SeeEwe or however it's spelled, is delicious here.  Great portions, always enough to take home. Also they have a full bar, and is right around the corner from the union where I intern at. This makes life convenient. 

The bartenders are pretty friendly and joke around a bunch, and it's pretty quiet if you want to catch up with friends and such.

Like this place a lot, woohoo.
author: Lauren S.

description: Not horrible, but for the prices, definitely not great. Seriously, some dishes are more expensive than Osha Thai, but Osha Thai at least tastes good. The duck curry was lacking in real flavor. The crispy pork fried rice was...unexpected. The pork was fried using the tempura batter I'm used to tasting on fried bananas, which is not a good thing. The eggplant and tofu (crispy) was not memorable, and the shrimp papaya salad was mediocre.  Honestly, hard to describe the dishes because they were just that nondescript.
author: ML N.

description:
I really like this place because its so close to the Orpheum. We came here for dinner before watching Wicked. The restaurant has tall ceilings and a large bar. There is a more loungey area to the left of the bar that seemed happenin'. We ended up sitting a cute table by the window. The menu is huge with a lot of variety. We ordered the grilled sirloin and the pad thai. Both were pretty good and decent in size. Of course we order cocktails (we were going to see a 2.5 hr show)! The wild orchid and the twisted thai tea were both delicious. This is a cute place and I will be back the next time I catch a show.

Get the Twisted Thai Tea. Really Like It. Repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description: My daughter and I decided to give this restaurant a try, seeing as it was close to the concert hall where we were going to see at Bill Graham.  We were seated immediately on a Saturday night, without reservations. It was a little weird to be so close to the noisy bar and lounge, but whatever!  The music and decor was so not Thai!  Motown classics blaring, odd wall mural...but my daughter loved it.  The food was surprisingly good too!  She had pad thai, which she had never had, and just devoured. I had grilled salmon, veggies and brown rice.  Yummy! Dessert for me was a whole, sliced juicy mango, and for her was fried banana with ice cream, drizzled with honey.  Bill came to $40.  Service was quick and very attentive.  We left contented!
author: Colleen B.

description: Terrible service, waited for 30 minutes and couldnt even put an order in. Food might be good, but didnt have the chance to try.
author: Ryan R.

description: Lalita is a cool place to hang out and sit back. People come here during happy hour and the menu is good with some pleasing appetizers. The owners and employees are really nice.
author: Matthew C.

description: Pretty good Thai food if you work in the area. I come here sometimes with co-workers.  It's your standard fare, but I think a little pricey for what you get and the location.
author: Julie P.

description:
There's really nothing "distinct" about this Thai food.  Unless they're talking about other things than the food.  

The food is okay.  I usually go there for lunch since it's just a couple of blocks from where I work.  It has more of a restaurant feel than most Thai places around here.  They have lunch specials for under $10 which are pretty decent.  I didn't realize that the main highlight of my meal there is the fried sweet potatoes which comes with the meal, until they forgot to give it to me once and I had a breakdown right there at the restaurant!  By the way, I think the food is 2 stars, but because of the sweet potatoes, I've upped it up to 3.

They have a pretty nice bar (for the area), but I'm not really supposed to drink during work hours, so I can't comment on their drinks..wink, wink!  nudge, nudge!

UPDATE 7/2007
I heard they had new owners, so I thought I'd stop by.  The food seemed to have improved, but sadly, no fried yams (sweet potatoes) with the lunch special anymore.  :(  I'll keep the stars the same in hopes that they'll bring it back.
author: Amihan M.

description: Decent Thai. Not the best but pretty darn good. My one issue here are the nuisance charges San Franciscans put up with; $2 extra for rice, $3.50 extra for peanut sauce. Weird nickel and dining brings me down. Just charge me the darn price and be done with it.
author: Richard G.

description: Too pricy for the incredibly average food. I try not to eat here if I can avoid it. The chicken katsu with friend rice was pretty good, but for the price I can get  a way better deal somewhere else. However, it does have a bar... and happy hour...
author: Jamie T.

description:
Love this place!

Food:  Delicious!  Prices and portions are reasonable, too.  Of course, some of the dishes are only meat and vegetables, which isn't satisfying for everyone.  Side of rice is just about $3, though - and it's nice to have a full bar there.

Service:  Everyone seems to have a good attitude, which is refreshing.  Also, one time we got little free bowls of rice/yellow bean/tapioca pudding when the check came out for some reason.

Atmosphere:  Pretty decor - murals and a koi pond and such.  Maybe it's a little overdone, but with $5 for an appletini, you probably won't mind.  It can get a little loud at the bar on weekends.

Lalita's a great choice if you want to grab some Thai in the TL.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I never thought that you could mess up pad see ew.  It always seemed like one of those dishes that you can rely on at any Thai restaurant.  Apparently I was wrong.  I got it to go the other day.  It was bland and flavorless.  There wasn't even sauce on many of the noodles.  It was just like eating greasy flavorless noodles.  Not pleasant.  It was also cold.  

I used to come here a lot.  I guess it comes with going to school next door.  Don't remember the pad see ew being this awful.  It was a chore to get through half of it.  Ugh.  

That being said, the service is good here.  I know some of the dishes here aren't that bad.  The décor is pretty interesting.  There is a lot of seating and it's good for groups.  The thai iced tea is pretty good.  Their to go service is super fast.  They also have a very good selection at the bar.  Would definitely recommend trying out the bar, but that pad see ew...
author: Alea G.

description:
The food was good. Not great. Overall clean and nice place. I would come back. It's close to the bart station/muni which is convenient. 
The price isn't the cheapest around. Wasn't too impressed but had a good time there. Again, food was good, thumbs up. Service was ah so so. Could be better.
author: Tania C.

description: Go for the décor and happy hours! There's a full bar and the appetizers are a bargain during happy hours. The menu items are good, but mild...not the most authentic. I gotta bust them for charging for tea. Ugh...I hate Asian restaurants that charge for tea. What I expect from an Asian establishment is for tea should hit my table before the water. Water when requested, but tea is a must! Free!
author: Helen L.

description:
On a recent trip to SF, my friends and I discovered Lalita.  What a lucky break for us!

We ate dinner here 5 or 6 times that week, and had a great experience every time.  The service was excellent, even when the place was full.  The prices were great - both for drinks and food.

We had several dishes that week - Pad Thai, Green Curry, Masaman Curry, Yellow Curry, Seafood Deluxe, Angel wings, shrimp rolls, and many more.  We were always happy with portion size and the flavors were fantastic.  The food always came out quickly, and everything was fresh and hot.  For those of you who don't know - Angel wings are boneless chicken wings stuffed with noodles.  Just great!

As for the bar, a Knob Creek on the rocks was $8.  It looked like they put in 4 ice cubes and filled the glass with bourbon - WHAT A DEAL!!!  

The Thai iced tea was good, and they do offer take-out service for the entire menu.

They have a great water feature in the front of the restaurant, with a rock fountain, greenery, and fish.  If you can sit near that, the water sounds are quite relaxing.

We will definitely go back next time we are in the area.
author: Andrew O.

description:
Absolutely the worst dining experience I can recall.  Arrived at 6 to make a show at the Golden Gate theater. Our party was 2 people and we each ordered a salad and an entree.  Salads came very quickly, but mine was drenched in dressing and my dining companion's came with dressing, although he'd asked for it on the side. Within 10 minutes, he had his salad as he'd ordered it.  45 minutes later, no entree.  His finally comes, but it's the wrong order.  They took his back, and 15 minutes later bring out the right order, but mine never comes.  By that time, we'd been there 1 hour and 35 minutes and I still have no entree and we have to leave for the theater.   Waitress was surly.  Manager kept saying "it'll be right out" but of course that didn't happen.  Cannot imagine how this place stays in business.

Also noticed the woman at the table next to ours got the wrong order and was upset, so it wasn't just us.
author: Jen A.

description: Been here once. Got the tofu Thai green curry and coconut juice. Food was good and quick. People were friendly. Decent but overpriced (cost me $15!). Might go back because it's close to my work but we'll see what my budget thinks.
author: Roxy B.

description: $23 for a pitcher. $23 for a pitcher of Anchor Steam. This is not a premium beer. This is not a premium restaurant. Shame on me for not asking first, but shame on them for charging such unreasonable prices. Never in my life have I walked into a bar expecting to pay more than $16 for a pitcher. Never. Zeitgeist charges $16 a pitcher, and that's for premium micro-brewed beer. Never again.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
WARNING***WARNING***WARNING

Do not order the calamari!!!  Went here in the evening, had my 6 yr old grandson and a friend. The place was way too dark. I like to be able to see my food clearly when I am out. I ordered fried calamari and some chicken/rice dish for grandson.   My friend ordered the calamari dinner.  Communication with the waitress was really bad. We could barely understand each other. So, after a lot of  pointing, slow deliberate annunnciating and attempts to reach common descriptives, we finally got through the order with her.  My grandson was irritated because he wanted the lights on, but we got another candle on the table instead. His dish arrived and he likes really plain food and seemed to like the rice dish. I tasted & it was very dull. It looked nothing like what I thought I had described to the waitress, though. My daughter always orders him a Thai dish with chopped chicken and rice on the side. What he received looked like mush, but that may have been due to the lighting.
The calamari in both dishes was SOOOO tough, we actually asked the waitress to return it to the chef. When we attempted to order something else, we were told we could not order anything. We had only taken two bites!  Well, she said she would remove the charges for our two dishes and reduce the chicken dish by 50%, but the bill still came to $27.00!!!! One beer, One lemondrop, and a half off meal.  Pricey right? We went home hungry and kicking ourselves for not going to our neighborhood bar, that makes the best damn calamari on this planet.
Martin Macks of course.
author: Miz E.

description:
I chose Thai food for NYE dinner....I went real spicy too..spoonfuls of the chile sauce on everything...I really should know my limit by now...after all these years...

On the BART ride home, at about 2:00am, damn chile made it's grand appearance in my vodka ladden belly, " Oh fffuuuuuu---"

Moving on....the restaurant was pretty and the service was great. The cucumber salad would have been delicious if it wasn't so sweet. The Garlic Pepper Beef was good but the Green Curry Chicken lacked the savory flavors that I so love and it was a little watery. 

Average food but If I was in the area I'd come back. They have a full bar and all...
author: Susie O.

description: Last dinner in San Fran. I got the cashew nut with chicken and brown rice, which were fine. Also got the veggie spring roll that came in a pack of four, but were only tasty enough for me to finish one. I'd call it a little pricey for its flavor but I've paid similarly for less quality in Atlanta, which keeps this from 2 stars
author: Jamarcus T.

description: Lalita has a comfortable atmosphere, friendly service, and decent Thai food.  However Lalita's bartender Winnie always has a smile on her face and crack jokes that makes your dinning and drinking that much better.
author: Chad L.

description:
This places ranges from dishes that are not bad (but not great) to plates that someone would have to pay me to eat.  I'm hardly a food snob, but that doesn't make my taste buds immune to horrible-tasting food.

Examples:

Decent: grilled rib-eye steak with steamed vegetables - not bad.  The beef was tender and had a char-grilled taste.  Nothing to write home about, but ok nonetheless.

Meh: stir fried eggplant and string beans - salty and garlic-y - two tastes that I don't mind, but the eggplant seemed really mushy and overcooked.  Also a bit on the oily side.  Also, beef noodle soup.  It was ok in the beginning because it was hot, but after awhile I couldn't eat anymore either because of the MSG, or the mystery meatballs.

WTH is this: sweet sticky rice with mango - I love this Thai dessert, but what I got here was kind of appalling.  It was a lump of sticky rice with condensed milk dumped over it.  The rice seemed like it was packaged and frozen for like.. 5 months and then defrosted.  Two thirds of it was HARD, like break a tooth hard.  The other one third was rubbery.  The mango was nice, but if all I wanted was a nice mango, I would've just gone to the market and bought.... a mango.  I was actually kind of angry that they would take my money and give me something so atrocious in return.  It was like someone was pulling a prank on me.

All of this was for pick up.  If I were eating at the restaurant, I would definitely have complained.

So yes. I'm not going here ever again.  As for all my fellow yelpers out there, I'd say maybe go for happy hour, but unless you are unnaturally appreciative of mediocre food, skip this place and go to Lers Ros.
author: CJ K.

description: Expsensive ($2-$3 dollars higher per entree than most thai places) for small portions and tasteless food. Had Pad Sie Yoo and Param. Much better thai places 2-3 blocks in any direction.
author: Dave Z.

description: Great place. Excellent food at decent prices. Amazing HH drinks and food. The area is a lil' crazy but that is part of the fun of being in the city ...people watching is fun here too. Sit in the bar for that of course.
author: Cherie F.

description: I come here every week after class for happy hour, and I've also come here for lunch once. It's not super fancy, but it's respectable. They serve Thai food, but it's also just a regular bar with all the regular drinks. It's a good place to go to just relax and have a drink. Most of the people who go are classmates or coworkers just chilling. There's no loud music or creepy people at the bar. The waitresses are friendly and helpful. We can be a rather boisterous crowd, but they're still patient and happy to get us anything we need.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Came here the other day and the cocktails were really bad. Had ordered a couple of margaritas and the glasses were so small that it looked like it came from a kids menu. All the cocktails here were so watered down It was debatable if it even had alcohol. 

The food here taste pretty much like Asian Fast Food. If Panda Express had Thai food, this would be how it would taste. Not saying the food was bad, just lacking. The tapioca dessert at the end had this weird flavor like basil leaf. 

The restrooms are so small and awkward one feels like they are urinating inside their closet.
author: M C.

description:
Hmmm. I could have sworn I already wrote about this place....

I was here for a happy hour quite a number of months ago. I was not impressed. Not with the ambiance, not with the service, not with the drinks, and most definitely not with the food. It took FOREVER to get someone to pay attention to us at the bar (and we're a group of beautiful women, no less!). We ordered drinks and some apps. The drinks, if I remember correctly, were OK, and certainly at happy hour prices. But the food! BLAH. I think it was among the worst tasting appitizers I'd ever had! Deep fried blah. 

We won't be having a happy hour here again.
author: Amy B.

description: Cool spot next to UC Hastings...huge space great happy hour with full bar. Love the Tom Kah soup and pumpkin curry is pretty good but the portion size is on the small side. Owner is very sweet and attentive to patrons. Our go to spot for a quick Thai fix.
author: William B.

description: TWO THUMBS UP!!!! The yellow curry vegetables were to die for!!! The drinks were strong and good.  I have nothing bad to say about this place and I definitely plan on going back!
author: Shay R.

description: This place is also by my school. A great hangout for AI students to mingle and grab a drink. They have a great happy hour for beer and appetizers, I would refer the calamari (really good). They are also pretty generous when it comes to making drinks. The place has a great atmosphere and staff, if you visit often they get to know you and hook you up sometimes. there have been times when I would walk in and the bar tender already had my drink waiting there for me, which was nice. Their food is awesome! I've never had anything bad there and it's consistent. I would refer the Grilled Honey Pork Salad, Basil Chicken Friend Rice, or the Grilled Roast Duck with Veggies. All of it is pretty good. So if your looking for a place to relax, eat, and grab a drink Lalita's is perfect.
author: Ryan C.

description:
My fiance went in here to eat on a Tuesday night. Not one other customer was in there, yet the service was still extremely slow. 

We had to wait and try to get the waitress several times. She decided her time was spent better chatting with the bartender than serving us. 

We ordered an appetizer and two dishes. One of the dishes was a Ginger beef , we each took a bite and spit it out. DISGUSTING! The beef did not even taste like beef it was chewy and we both could not eat it. 
I took us several minutes to flag down the waitress to send it back and order something else. The chicken they replaced it with was sub-par, nothing special.

The crab rice we ordered tasted like it was 4 days old and was microwaved for us before putting it on the table, SERIOUSLY DISGUSTING! i do not go out to eat to eat left-overs.

Whatever you do DO NOT eat here! The terrible food goes right next to the terrible service
author: Alyssa O.

description: My go to happy hour spot during the week. The bartender Winnie is awesome, we dont even need to order because she knows what we want right when we get there. The food is really good. Appetizers for $3.50 until 7 and beers on tap are the same. Sports is usually on and the other regulars are friendly. The dinner menu is a bit pricey but you'll understand when the food comes because everything tastes great. i'll be seeing you soon LALITA!
author: Frank T.

description:
I often come to Lalita's for Happy Hour against my will. Due to its proximity to school and my apartment, my friends and I always wind up here before class, after class, and even in between classes for a little buzz and a few munchies. But I don't like it--I don't like it at all.

The food is mediocre at best and the service is borderline rude. I'm only here when the rent is due and I'm broke from eating at Harris Steakhouse, Slanted Door, and Roy's Restaurant (twice) last week. During Happy Hour, beer and wine are only $3.50 and appetizers are only $3.95. The corn fritters, egg rolls, and fried calamari are ok, but left me reminiscing about all the better corn fritters, egg rolls, and fried calamari I've had at other places.

I'll be back because it's a good place to catch up and I can't really escape the Tenderloin for whatever reason, but I'll be wishing I was sipping a lava flow somewhere in a hammock by the beach--or at least more than 20 feet away from bums, crackheads, and prostitutes.
author: Liz T.

description: Their chicken red curry has GREAT flavor without the spice (I am not a fan of spice).  The service is always friendly.  Well balanced menu.
author: Amanda Y.

description:
I've been riding and walking past this place for four years, and I've always wanted to eat here some day.  

Tonight I dropped in for happy hour, thanks to Matt H's rallying cry.  I felt a little uneasy, and I left.  Upon reflection, I realized the main thing wrong was that my head was still at work, and I hadn't gotten happy yet.  So back in I went.  

The dining area was empty, but the bar was full.  It was a little crowded, and a little static.  I had to squeeze between tables and the bar to get to the back lounge area, where everyone was happily not hearing each other.  But wait, it got better.  Sitting down changed my perspective a lot.  My face was close to someone else's, and we could talk!  

The drinks were cheap; $3 for a rum & Coke during happy hour, and $4 afterwards.  The conversation was great, because great people were there to talk.  The scenery was first-class; some people almost grew eye extensions to see what other people were wearing.  Someone shared some calamari, which was delicious as calamari always is, and one of the ladies present was talking like a sailor.  

Somehow, when I'm munching on squid and listening to a lady talk like a squid, it all comes together.  

I still want to eat here some day.
author: David D.

description:
I went to this place twice for happy hour, first time the service wasn't that great but I like the food and beers so gave it another try last week but even worst service! Very very bad attitude/ service from the bartender/ waitress! We ordered two different kind of beers and she just placed it in front of us, so we asked her which is which... and her F**KING answer was so rude.... she said " This is sierra and that is blah blah (forgot the name of the other beer we ordered), couldn't you tell". We were shock.... Stupid Bitch... if we know which is which, we wouldn't have to ask you! 
If you want to serve with this kind of attitude, go to this wonderful place!! But I will never go to this place again!!
author: K W.

description:
I've always seen this place on my ride home on the 5.  I've always thought to myself, "Self...I think I am curious about this place.  Lets check it out."  Lo and behold DYL turns this place out as a location for drinking...and myself's thoughts were made a reality.  However, maybe, and that's a big maybe, I'd come back to eat here again.  Maybe.

But to come here as a bar, negatory.  

We started the night off by securing a nice little cushioned area in a crowded corner of the "bar" area, and after having to get up, and grab the ONE bartenders attention, we finally got service.  Now, they do have a pretty killer happy hour.  $3 wells, wines and drafts, and $4 appetizers, but its not the kind of bar I'm looking to frequent, even for a great happy hour. I'm hoping that the appetizers were actually sold happy hour size for happy hour, because if I was to receive the order of wings I did at an actual table, I'd be pretty disappointed.

Did you know that chickens are really self conscious about their weight?  They must be, because I think we were served the anorexic Basil wings, seeing as though the amount of meat that were on them was enough for one small, and I mean really small, bite.  But hey...for happy hour prices, who am I to judge.  The potstickers were decent, and the calamari was tasty, and I might try the real menu some day....but with all the other awesome Thai restaurants in the city...and all the new reviews to be written...why bother.
author: Lauren F.

description:
YES! a gem in the shadiest part of SF for a 5-block radius.
YES! great location
YES! fabulous ambiance (great decorating)
YES! amazing food (full of flavor!!!)
...exactly what i was craving when i was craving a great place with good food and fantastic ambiance.
(PS, turn off the tv's while i'm eating)
author: Candice T.

description:
I should be tarred and feathered for planning DYL here a few weeks back. No. The stingy staff at Lalita should be tarred and feathered for pouring lilliputian drinks and charging not-so-happy-hour prices for them. The food didn't look outstanding and I was overall disappointed with the crowd, space, and general operation of Lalita. 

Slow, slow service + miniature, weak drinks = irritable, painfully sober, ready-to-cut-a-bitch AK. I won't be back and I apologize for this grave lapse in judgement. 2 stars because it's pretty clean, restrooms were large and neat, and it's convenient to downtown/BART.
author: Autumn K.

description: It's moments like this where I am really proud to have the "maverick" badge on Yelp...hahaha! Why the heck is this place only 3.5 stars? The food was delicious! I had just finished hot yoga on a Friday night and I was high off of my natural endorphins. I was walkin' the streets of SF on my way to a sushi restaurant (I am serious when it comes to my cravings). Someone in the group didn't feel like walking 0.8 miles and so we stumble across this place. It was pretty empty but the bar was happening! We take our seats and I'm a little skeptical. You know how you are craving one dish but you have to settle for another? OMG best detour decision ever! Joshua R. ordered the roasted duck, I had the duck noodle soup and our friend ordered the seafood pad thai. We left with our plates clean. Like, was there food on those plates a half hour ago? The lady was super sweet in addressing all of my indecision on the menu! She recommended amazing dishes and it was simply great service and great food! As for drinks, we kept it simple. For some reason, they didn't have Singha beer but they had other great choices. I ordered the Chivas Regal and our friend ordered a very female drink. I wish I had room for dessert. I felt so amazing, I was ready to curl up in my bed and call it a night because it couldn't have gotten better after that meal!
author: Leena B.

description: Happy hour is not bad. Go to this place because close to work. Not too fancy. Bartender remembers you.  Just very comfortable for a quick happy hour. $3.50 beers and drinks.
author: Maria M.

description:
I love their lunch special!  I especially love the deep fried goodies that come with it. It has a nice atmosphere and even a little waterfall. I am a fan. It is also very close to my school. The service is always very prompt and friendly. 

Yum!

UPDATE: 1/31/07: Downgraded from 5 stars
I am starting to strain on their prices.  You can't get a soup for under $7 which is pretty hefty.  Also, they *suddenly* don't provide free refills on fountain sodas.  The waiter insisted that they never did but I remember otherwise.  It really irritates me when restaurants do this-- especially when charging a normal soda price ($1.75).  I go there a lot so I don't think that they should have been so snark about it.  I think I am just kind of pissed today.
author: H B.

description:
The food is good, traditional Thai-the way it's supposed to be. No gimmicks, so if you're looking for the new trendy, expensive fusion Thai restaurants, this isn't for you. The food is awesome, but THE BAR is the place to be. Great happy hour drink specials, and now they last until 7 so I can go for a Guiness after work. $3 Drafts? BRILLIANT. Oh and the appetizers are SWEET. Corn fritters, mmmm...shrimp rolls, mmmmm.....a martini glass filled with fried yams and a peanut crusted rim? MMMMMM!!!! But I must admit, I come here more often because the bartender not only remembers my name and drink, he's pretty cute too. 
;)
author: Adrienne F.

description:
I don't understand this place.  Either 1) they are really a chain, hiding under the guise of a family run business or 2) they are a money laundering scheme.  

The food is not very good and it's quite expensive.  I've quit coming here for lunch or dinner and now ONLY come in for Happy Hour.  Although, now that I think about it, I never end up leaving very happy...

The place gets loud, the lightening is red (hence gives you painful flash backs to that "hotel-that-one-night-in-Amsterdam") and the service is actually quite terrible.  So, why do we keep coming here?  Well, the booze is cheap!!  And, that is usually all that matters.  

That, and, at least in the past year, the Happy Hour appetizers have improved slightly.  The fried calamari is pretty decent, although small; it comes out on a bed of rice noodles and covered in a sweet chili sauce.  The wings are also good; spicy and not overcooked.  

I'd skip the corn fritters (what's a "fritter" anyhow?  Just a wanna-be pancake, right?) and the chicken satay.
author: Val K.

description:
Before attending a show at the Orpheum, we ate here barely catching happy hour literally down to the minute.  My theater companion made sure that she grabbed the bartender just moments before happy hour expired.  She ensured that we got 2 drinks each and 4 appetizers to share at discounted prices.

I am not sure that it was too Thai per say but I enjoyed all four dishes we shared.  I can't speak to the strength of the mixed drinks because I stuck to beers on tap.  I was satisfied with everything.
author: Tracy A.

description: I come here often and the food gets a 9/10 and the bar gets a 10/10 during happy hour.  I'd give them a full 5 starts if they handled people better; I came in one night recently and the bar seating was full.  The dinner seating was almost empty.  I just wanted a few happy hour drinks and an appetizer, but they refused to seat me in the wide-open dinner section unless I promised to order dinner.  As a regular, not so happy.  I decided to go along with it and said I would, but I wanted to relax and have a drink before ordering.  The servers kept coming over and bugging me and my buddy to order, even though we still had the menus open.  The dinner section was almost empty so we weren't keeping anyone else from ordering.  I thought it was rude.
author: Elisabeth G.

description:
Update:
I went back and now the appetizer's aren't as good as they once were before the renovation.  The wings are really mediocre now and nothing gets on my nerves than a restaurant messing with a good wing recipe.  The rest of the food is decent, but nothing special.  Demoted one star.

*****************************************
Happy hour love baby.  

M-F, 3-6pm: $3 drinks and $4 appetizers  Now the only problem I have with that is that it ends at 6 pm.  I mean who gets out of work and starts drinking at 3?  

Well if you're lucky enough to get off work early this is a damn fine establishment to start your evening.  Cheap alcohol, pretty good appetizers and it's off in a random ass corner of the city so you mostly have the place to yourself.  Which is nice if you're with a group of people.  

We had crab wontons, calamari and the highlight of my trip would be the wings.  Juicy deep fried little bad boys with a sweet honey sauce.  Surrounded by deep fried basil leaves.  Mmm.. got me drooling for some more.  Normally I like my wings spicy but these sweet things seriously had me licking my fingers like nobody's business.  

I can't wait to go back and try some more of their menu.
author: Ke-Bear Z.

description:
Definitely over priced for what you get. The place looks cool and clean, but the food is poor quality. The chicken satay was decent but expensive for only 4 skewers. All the beef I've eaten here has been chewy and stringy. Not appetizing at all. After what they served me today, I give up on them. 

If Lalita wasn't across the street from my job, I wouldn't of given them as many chances as they've gotten.
author: Jayme J.

description: Best Thai food I've found in San Fran.  Crispy pumpkin app is amazing...as is the Panang curry.  I would give it five stars except the place smells awful because they have an overgrown fish pond in the corner.  Once the food comes, you don't notice really, but before that...yuck.
author: John Z.

description:
I like beef.

I like rice.

I like spicy sauce over beef and rice.

Lalita's makes this happen for me.  Even better, when I tell the waitstaff that I only have a limited time for lunch, they do their best to get the food and the bill out quickly.  I'm a creature of habit, so I always get the same dish and can't speak to anything else on the menu, but Lalita's is definitely one of the nicer places in the 'hood.  And if you're feeling adventerous, you can take a lovely after dinner stroll up Leavenworth.
author: Jess T.

description:
This is one of the best places to eat and drink in the 'loin.  The bartender is a sweetie, and the owner is often there to help out.  She's a rock star!  If you want to change something, they are accommodating with special requests.  Some of the dishes are a little mellow, which appeals to the non-adventurous types or 1st time Thai fooders.  But if you ask for spicy, they will give you spicy!

The appetizers are yummy goodness.  The drinks are liquid yummy goodness.

ETA:  The last time I stopped by during summer 2007 I found out that Lalita has sold the restaurant.  I didn't actually try any food that day, so I may have to revise my ranking after trying the food under new management.
author: Nikki c.

description:
Absolute worst customer service I've ever encountered.  I've had multiple incidents where the bartender/server was not helpful and did not acknowledge me whatsoever.  I'm not an uptight person and don't need to be pampered, but come on, just because you are in a convenient location between my work and Civic Center does not mean you have to be rude.

Secondly, and most importantly, they overcharged my credit card.  No, I will not let you get away with this, Lalita.  This is credit card fraud.  I would warn anyone who is going there to check their balance compared to your receipt.

Also, the math genius behind the bar said pints of Sierra Nevada were $4.50, I ordered a pitcher (4 beers) and they charged me $20.  Great.  I let that one go but now that I see you overcharged my card, I'm expressing my grievances over the internet and in person.  See you in 15 minutes during busy lunch hour.
author: Christopher M.

description:
I had to step over a homeless junkie who was defecating on himself in the entryway, let's just say that ruined the evening.

3 stars for mediocre Thai food with very friendly and attentive service.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Looking for a place to grab a quick bite before a weekday show at the Orpheum. Found it, and the wife and I were quite pleased! We ordered the fried mushrooms to start, and then shared the chicken Pad Thai and the Mussman Lamb Curry. The mushrooms were tasty, the curry was creamy and delicious, and the Pad Thai was a mountainous serving that I found delicious and not too sticky (as it sometimes is). The staff was on top of refilling our drinks, and very nice and respectful overall. 

Another thing that earned them big points in my mind was that an older disheveled man (may or may not have been homeless - didn't talk to him) wandered in off the street and our waiter appeared to be sent over to "handle it" and make sure he didn't disturb the patrons. Without being in on their conversation, I noticed our waiter speaking nicely with the man (smiling and putting his hand on the man's shoulder). He showed the man to the restroom and helped him sit down at the bar and have a glass of water for a few minutes. The man eventually went on his way, but the memory of good people working here will have me coming back almost as much as the tasty food. My rating was done just on the food quality, and I will definitely be back.
author: Tim Q.

description: I was really disappointed by the service I received here. I've been here a while ago and loved the basil chicken wings, but recently only saw angel wings on the menu. I asked the server if those were the chicken wings which he said yes, so I ordered them to find that that's a different dish. He didn't offer to change the dish when I said I didn't see basil wings on the menu. He flipped through the menu, didn't find the dish either, but said they can add it for me so I agreed to pay for a second fried chicken dish. It still wasn't the same dish that I loved. He told me after that they've changed owners and chefs.
author: Diana B.

description:
A bit surprised by all of the not-so-great reviews on this place.  We came here on the Friday night after Thanksgiving, so it's not really fair to judge the empty place on a Friday night (figure everyone was at home eating leftovers).

The restaurant is big and spacious--refreshing considering it's SF.  

Regular thai-dishes.  While the place wasn't spectacular, I especially enjoyed the tofu and peanut-sauce.  Chicken in the curry was a bit dry.

$190 for a group of 7 (including one drink each) was a great deal.  Overall, fantastic prices and very decent food.  Oh, and it's a very short walk to/from the Orpheum theater.
author: Marcia L.

description: Seeking a restaurant close to the Orpheum for dinner we decided to give Lalita Thai a try.  Although a few of the reviews on Yelp were somewhat harsh, the only complaint we could agree with was the sweet sauce on the crispy calamari that really didn't add anything.  Other dishes were very good, reasonably priced, and the portions were more than adequate.  Would definitely go again
author: Jeanine G.

description:
Yuck.  This place only gets stars for its happy hour prices of yummy strong drinks.  Aside from getting boozed up in the Tenderloin, you should have no real reason to come here.   

The food is tres bland and rubbery/dry.  Whatever you order, you'll get these two characteristics.  I swear!  Even the soup --- bland and there's something rubbery or dry in there.

You rarely see people here sitting with plates of food --- most of them are sitting by the bar getting sloshed or sitting a bit too long for that really hot bartender who's there at nights.  That should say something...
author: Guava C.

description: I live near Lalita so I eat here pretty often when I don't have time to cook.  The atmosphere is pretty nice (except for the sketchy-looking dark space in the back of the restaurant area) and the food is good.  I wish they had a better eggplant dish.  The dishes are expensive but they give a lot of food, so I usually have enough food for another leftover meal.
author: Laura W.

description:
We went there for happy hour yesterday.  It was okay.  The appetizers, though tasty, were not particularly sizable, and the premises were a bit on the dark side.  The experience was probably dampened somewhat by the fact that right before coming in, I'd spent five minutes arguing with an SUV driver who scraped my fender and then claimed that I had no business trying to leave a parking space at the same moment that she was planning on cutting in front of me.  

I guess I'd go back, but probably when there's less traffic.
author: moosedog i.

description:
Oooh, the food.  The food is soooo good.

First tried Duck Curry here, and have never found better-- also recommend the green beans with peanut sauce, and of course the pad thai.

The wait staff are very friendly also-- the warm welcome is just as appealing as the food!
author: Kelly A.

description:
This place is weird. I went in with a group of people in the late afternoon and we just wanted a quick pitcher so we could talk about some work we were doing. We stood at the bar and bartender lady kept yelling at us to sit down on the bar stools. We didn't want to sit down all in a row, because we were clearly talking about something. We weren't blocking the way... there wasn't even a lot of people in there. Then she also tried to strong arm us into ordering food and was super annoyed when we didn't. Chill out bartender lady! Geez! 

Also, she gave us a bunch of really tiny glasses (like juice glasses??) to drink our beer out of us. Super weird. Will not be going back.
author: J J.

description:
i would normally give a place of this quality 2 stars. HOWEVER there are a few redeeming qualities of lalita that make the bump to three stars necessary

- happy hour prices for drinks are good.

- happy hour deals for apps (although not necessarily the best tasting, go well with the cheap drinks)

- it is close to my apartment and school so that if i get super hungry and dont want to walk far i know that i can always come here.

-the SPINACH TOFU SOUP. it is, srsly, a hidden gem on the menu. super simple. super tasty. super satisfying.  it is a shame that it basically costs 10 bucks (when i know that i could make my own for much cheaper. and to be honest all that cooked spinach gives me a weird mouth feel) but in the end i dont care. it is delish and when i am in the mood for it nothing else will satisfy.
author: Jason B.

description:
* happy hour review only * 4-7pm M-F

$3.50 pints, $3.50 well drinks, and like sub $4 appetizers.

i only stumbled upon this place b/c my buddy goes to law school and this is across the street, and i happen to have lots of time on my hands current (ie unemployed).

so for me (unemployed) and him (student), and his classmates, you can't beat it for the price!  and the service is prompt, friendly, and comes with a smile.
author: Jason J.

description: i always love coming to lalita.  the bartender and waitresses always offer excellent, cheerful and spunky service.  the pad see ew is my absolute favorite dish, and they do an excellent job!  they also have great happy hour with apps and drinks.
author: Djamila D.

description:
I've had better, but this place def looks pretty nice on the inside, if a little bit too dark. I mean, there are plenty of other Thai places around that give the same food for generally a lesser price

Nothing to write home about, but they did cater to 16 of us pretty OK though. Their Thai Iced Tea was a little too sweet though...
author: Dustin H.

description:
Happy Hour - 5 stars
M-F, 3-6pm: $3 for (select)  beer/wine/cocktail and $4 appetizers.  

I like food A LOT so this is a great place to get a something-something with my drink.  Only downside - with the great food comes limited choices in happy hour drinks.  Oh well, can't have it all I guess.

Lunch/Dinner - 3 stars
Only so-so food for the price but you're paying for the ambience.

Side note: Service is always nice. Bartenders are great and the owners are awesome people.
author: Bessie T.

description:
I go because it is close to work.  I think that the taste depends on what you eat.  I had a unique, yet delicious pad see-ew, but found the pad thai way too salty (and I love salt!)  Found myself guzzling water all afternoon after lunch, as if there were not enough water in the world . . .

I agree that the price is higher than it should be.
author: Jane L.

description:
I ate here once a while ago and remembered the food being okay enough, and that the mixed drinks were  really good.  Went back last night and was not impressed by the drinks (didnt try the food).  

They used to have a drink called something like the wild orchid, which could knock you on your ass.  The drink last night didnt have that much alcohol in it, at least I didnt get that warm feeling one should get after drinking an alcoholic cocktail.  

If I remember right, Lalita (the owner) was going to sell the place, and I think it's under new ownership, which might explain the down slide.  Still, if your looking for a relatively quiet and decent place to grab some food and drink in the Tenderloin after dark, you could do a hell of a lot worse.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
This place used to kick ass. 

Strong drinks, cheap AMAZING happy hour food, and great service.

Now, Lalita is under new ownership and everything has just gone to shit. The portions got smaller, the prices went up, the quality went down, and they took off my favorite appetizer!

Oh..Oh...and they ALWAYS overcharge me when I order take out and force me to get into a weird fight with the manager!

But the yellow chicken curry is good. I will give them that.
author: Keila E.

description:
Their crispy basil chicken is sooo good!  

The red curry with egg plant and tofo is good too!
author: Jessica L.

description:
If you're going here for drinks, it's all right. Horrible, extremely slow service, but prices make it bearable. Then again, it being right next to my school is the only reason I'd really go here.

The food ranges from bad to great. I have had every appetizer on the menu due to school functions. They're all pretty good, but the crispy basil beef is incredible. It's really the only thing I find noteworthy about Lalita at all.

The entrees are pretty mediocre and generally overpriced. ($2.50 for brown rice when white rice is included in the price is a bit odd.) There are much, much better places a few blocks into the TL (Bang San!), but they're all holes-in-the-wall, whereas Lalita is a pretty nice place.
author: Phatalie J.

description:
let's see. new ownership.

The first time we went back...it was a disaster!!
we ordered bloody mary, margarita, cosmo, all suck!! the appertizer which used to be our favorite were travesties...

but i went back for lunch a couple of times and every dish i've had so far were more than good. it's a little pricy for a lunch otherwise i would go back more often than i feel rich enough to....

appertizer is still disaster...sliced beef was overcooked and underseasoned. chicken satay was acceptable but how much further you wanna go?

the drinks got a little better i think but i couldn't remember...

i recommend it for lunch, on occasions, when you feel rich or necessarily rich...or down and need some up rewards....
author: Xiu L.

description:
Good Thai food for a decent price.  Conveniently located by Hastings and the library.  Full Bar, great specialty drinks ( I should know, I used to bartend there).  Great happy hour prices, both on food and drink.

The bar features Blue Moon Beer, and I normally don't drink beer, but this one is good!

Only wished that it was more lively during the late hours, but being near the TL and businesses that don't open past 6pm, not many bar patrons to make it a "happening" spot to hang out.

Try the Duck fried rice!  and The Pink (for those grapefruit lovers).
author: Eric W.

description:
Went here by chance, we actually came to see Muse awhile back. 

Screw the round the block line, Thai food, here we come.

All I can say is YUM to the TUM to the TAH TAH TAH TUM.

I love!
author: LiZANN S.

description:
After several bad experiences at Lalita, I went against my better judgement and decided to join a group of friends from work for an after-hours drink.  Never again!  I know there is a saying, "Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me."  I have been shamed one too many times.

Bad food.  Overpriced drinks.   And the insult to injury is the unbearable service.  I love a nice banter and don't mind a little attitude, but Lalita's is downright mean.  

Thank god for Aunt Charlies right around the corner.

ps - this is my first YELP post ever.
author: Karl R.

description:
I went here for a lunch with my boss at first. For a good looking restaurant, the price is pretty good. The portion of the food is big! I am not sure how authentic these thai food are, but they are pretty good. 

I came again for the bar. Happy hour is a good deal, about $3.5 for a draft beer and about $4 for the appetizer, and they are all decent. The bartender here was really nice to me. 

I will definitely come back here for more!
author: Abel W.

description: So I live across the street at the Hastings tower and I've been here countless times but it's the first time I'm reviewing it.  So after going here for over 2 years, I can say that this place is pretty damn good.  Their happy hour is an absolute bargain with cheap drinks and appetizers.  The management is always accommodating for non-profit fundraisers Hastings holds there.  The service is very good and my water cup is never empty.  The price to quality of food ratio is pretty high.  I usually don't pay any more than 12 bucks for a large portioned, tasty entree.  I definitely recommend this place despite what anyone else says.
author: David Y.

description:
I've been there for lunch since I work nearby, and it's pretty solid.  Last time I had the pumpkin curry special, it was very good.  The mango sticky rice was delicious and above average.

Some work friends and I went there for happy hour on a Monday, and it wasn't exactly busy, but the drink specials were decent at $3.50 a pop.  The appetizers were cheap, but the only ones I really liked was the calamari and the corn fritters.  I like the place OK for H.H. but I like to have more of a crowd and it just wasn't happening on a Monday.  Maybe on a Thursday or Friday?
author: Scott G.

description: It was dark and wednesday. Was getting ready to party.. I was damn hungry. I live in the TL.. I'm po' I got pad thai and it was bland and expensive! The fried fish cakes were no good either.. and it cost me 20 dollars!!!!! For an app and an entree??? Do Not waste your money at Lalita Thai.(peiod)
author: Stephfon B.

description:
Went for lunch with my father. The service was quick and, though it wasn't full, there was a good amount of people in the restaurant. We ordered the calamari appetizer, and I got the chicken with spicy basil sauce, dad got the steak. 

I love me some calamari. I prefer the salt and pepper Chinese style calamari, with diced jalapenos, but this was just as good. It had a lighter batter, and a sweet sauce drizzled over it.

My chicken dish was pretty good. I definitely prefer the spicier end of the spectrum though, so when I order something spicy, I expect it to be so. This had a definite spice to it, but was below my expectations. Taste-wise, it was excellent though, lots of flavor. Rice is a dollar extra, and for another extra dollar, you can substitute brown rice.

I had a piece of the steak, and it had a decent crust and good flavor.

The thai iced tea was a bit pricey, but it was also a pretty decent sized glass.
author: Adam P.

description: I eat here all of the time! This is my baseline Thai - it's my measuring stick for other thai restaurants, if you will. Pra Ram and rainbow curry are both great. Appetizers are yummy and especially cheap during their long happy hour. Lunch menu is streamlined and lunch service is fast even when they're busy. Portions are good at both lunch and dinner. Prices aren't unreasonable. Full bar and the bartender Winnie is pretty funny.
author: Erin M.

description:
The biggest draw is definitely the full bar!  The drinks are strong and this was the only thai restaurant  we could find within walking distance of our hotel that had a decent selection of vegetarian options plus a full bar.  The full bar is a requirement for me and my boyfriend when we go out to eat and thai restaurants rarely have the bar!   But, the drinks were very tasty!

The food was very good.  We were happy they had a decent selection of vegetarian dishes.  We got the egg rolls, yellow curry, and a noodle dish.  The noodle dish was very good!  The fried tofu in the yellow curry was not the best, but the curry itself was very tasty!  Maybe soft tofu would have tasted better.  Although the food was not the most amazing thai I've ever had, it was definitely very tasty.

I liked the ambience.  It was moderately dark, but I like dark restaurants for dinner on a Saturday night.  The mural on the wall is very pretty and the fountain made it more pleasant.  The wait staff was very friendly, although a tad on the slow side.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Went here on a business lunch.  I had the red vegetable/ tofu curry and rice.  Quite good.  Fresh ingredients, tasty curry...albeit a little bland, needed the garlic chili sauce on the side.  Great space and excellent people watching.  Maybe free wireless around as a saw a woman working away on her laptop.

I would go back but a bit far a walk for lunch hour.
author: Aberdo G.

description: Decent food, decent happy hour, and good portion sizes
author: Alannah N.

description: My boyfriend and I went here looking for the closest place to eat so we weren't expecting much. It was a great find! It was hard for us to decide what to eat because everything sounded so good. We ended up with calamari for an appetizer, I ordered the dancing prawns, and he ordered pad thai. Everything was yummy and we were both full by the end of the meal! The decor is also super cute and our waiter was very friendly. I'm not sure about parking but it's really close to the Civic Center BART.
author: Janice F.

description:
I was here last Thursday with some friends, and we had a long lunch and migrated over to the bar for happy hour at 3:30. By then there were four of us hanging out, and three of us ordered drinks and an appetizer.

The waitress looks over at my friend that did not order a beverage and says "one drink minimum per person" and insinuated that she would have to leave if she did not order a drink.

 Now mind you, Lalita's is not a strip club. Nor does it provide other varieties of  entertainment. It is just a restaurant/bar that gets a ton of business from Hastings students like us. Which makes me think that the waitresses need to learn some manners and not make up bitchy rules to encourage people to order $3.50 drinks. Because people will leave if you don't make them feel welcome.
author: Masha B.

description: the food was alright. the service was a little cold. we were shoved back into a corner because it was busy. it kinda is in a bad neighborhood.
author: Clayton B.

description:
Oh, give me a break!  Who orders steak in a Thai restaurant?

This is the perfect spot for happy hour and pre-show.  Great bar staff, terrific appetizers, and very good Thai food if you choose to have a sit-down dinner.

Marina pursey-poos go home!
author: Paul H.

description:
If you drive by, you'll notice the bright neon lights on the exterior.  This does not translate to the inside where the bar area has a really comfortable lounge feeling to it.  

Go for the HAPPY HOUR and stay for the food.  The happy hour drinks are cheap and deep.  Good size pours, I normally drink Scotch on the rocks but I had several Glenrothes 1997 single malt and it was only $5.00.  This is a $8.00 drink at any other bar in the city and its about $14.00 at Aqua's.  So the drinks are poured deep and they are cheap.

My friend was drinking Beer, Anchor Steam, offered during happy hour.  I think the Pint size beer was $3.00 this is cheap too. It might had been two for one?? But who knows, I was drinking Scotch. The Bar is nice where you can have a conversation with others.  It's not so noise that you are yelling at one another.  The Bar tender was this cute Asian girl, who kept a descent conversation and not difficult to look at.  But really come of the drinks and the food.

Yesterday, I tried had the Duck Fried rice.  The blend between salty and sweet was a perfect match.  The rice was not heavy with oil and MSG. The food had clean flavors and was not greasy like many other Thai restaurants.  The Basil Chicken, breast of chicken sliced, had a mild (requested) spice and sweet blend of the red peppers. 

I was extremely happy at the end of the meal.  Good size portions where you're satisfied and not stuffed.  

Parking is really easy in the area, I parked on McAllister noticed that there were a lot of spaces.  

After dinner, Since we were only a couple of blocks to the clubs, we tanked up on cheap drinks and grabbed a cab.  

I think that Lalita Thai Restaurant is a great place after work for a drink or two...well maybe three.  

Look for me, I'll be the happy guy at the end of the bar drinking Glenrothes by the bottle.
author: heavy h.

description:
My experience has been limited to countless trips to the bar section of the place.

I've been coming here since I moved last month. Outrageously awesome Happy Hour. $3 for a pint of Guinness, Blue Moon, or Pilsner Urquell? Hell yes! My only qualm is that they don't have oranges for the Blue Moon, so they use Lemons.

The bartender introduced me to my new favourite drink... the Ginger Lemon Drop. It's a perfectly tart and potent Lemon Drop with the sting and spice of Ginger. Absurdly good!
The appetizers are fairly priced during Happy Hour, and definitely worth its weight in awesomeness. I recommend the fried calamari. They somehow get an amazing fried batter that doesn't sog easily from the sweet chili sauce.

LEET!
author: Phasouk S.

description:
I honestly don't know how the rating is even above a two for this restaurant. My husband and I went there today for dinner (it was my birthday)  before going to the theater and the food was devastatingly awful and overpriced. We ordered:
- Veggie egg rolls (certainly nothing to write home about - I've had tastier ones at more decent prices)
- Beef appetizer (suggested by the server) - Drier than the Mojave 
- Special of the night (another suggestion by the server): salmon cooked in a banana leaf served with a sad excuse for sides - veggies and mashed potates and gravy (just guessing on the latter because I couldn't get myself to try it)
- Mojitos - ew! The first attempt was like drinking a lime soda. Server was kind enough to get it remade only to get the second batch tasting like we were gulping syrup.

Overpriced and sadly disappointing. Don't waste your money. Make the trip out to Osha off of the Montgomery Bart stop. You'll be thanking me later. The only plus, a pretty nice server.
author: O C.

description: Lalita, humdrum of my day, ennui of my lunch.  No spice, no soul.  La-lee-ta:  it hits the tip of the tongue taking a trip of three steps down the palate to tap, at tedium, on the tonsil.  La.  Lee.  Ta.  It was La, plain La, on the plate, pad eggplant stir-fry with tofu.  It was boring at lunch.  It was par at dinner.  It was average at the bottom line.  But in my mouth it was merely Lalita.  Did it have a precursor?  It did, indeed it did.  In point of fact, lunch might have been no Lalita at all had I not loved, one meal, an initial Thai place.  In a mini-mall by the highway.  Oh when?  About as many years before Lalita was opened as my age was that summer.  You can always count on a finicky man for exacting dining style.  Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, meal number one is what the masses, the misinformed, hungry, noble-tongued masses, envied.  Taste this lack of flavor.
author: Kevin H.

description: We went to Lalita because the reviews on Yelp indicated that it was a great choice... We had concert tickets and arrived almost 3 hours before our show.  The place was NOT busy when we arrived, and we were content as we were seated.  We ordered, our appetizer came, (corn fritters) devine!  After waiting another 35 minutes for our dinner, I asked what the problem was: 5 other tables were seated, ordered and served in this time!  The food was very good.  The service was the worst we have EVER experienced!  We will NOT return.
author: Cecelia M.

description: Came here one night before catching Wicked. My friend and I didn't order much..eggplant with beef, pad thai, & pad kee mao. It was a decent meal, nothing too extraordinary. The ambiance was cute & I kinda wish I ate on the happy hour side..oh well. Their rose tea was sooooo good! I'd come back here to dine when I catch another show at the Orpheum. It's so close and convenient. The prices are very good and reasonable..especially for the city. I'll be back..but this time on the chic bar lounge area.
author: Empee P.

description: I just moved i across the street from this place and when I saw that it had a full bar I knew I'd be spending a lot of time hear. Luckily the place rocks. The first couple of times I went there it was for happy hour drinks $3.50 beers and cocktails, nice :-) Also had a couple of appetizers which were very good, the fried mushrooms being the best. I've since had the Pad Sew Ee (?) which was a bit bland but I gave it a healthy dose of chili sauce and it livened up a bit, and the other night I ordered the Roast Duck Red Curry...wow! it was tastetastic. On top of that Winnie the bartender and Vincent the owner introduced themselves to me and my roommate after recognizing us as potential new regulars. This place gets my recommendation. Good food, cheap drinks, and nice people? Check, check, and check
author: Andrus H.

description: First time I've been back since they changed ownership awhile ago. I had the red curry with tofu & vegetables. Service was wonderful, but the food, not so good. The curry was bland, and I found a piece of beef hanging out in the bottom of the bowl. Our server was very apologetic when I mentioned that vegetarians don't appreciate when you cook the vegie food in the same pan as the beef curry. Probably won't go back.
author: Wan T.

description: Decent Thai.  Nice decor.  Lunch specials.  If you are doing jury duty at the Civic Center Courthouse, this is the place to go on your hour lunch break - the walk to and from the restaurant, ordering, and eating gives you just enough time to go back through security, use the bathroom and get back to the courtroom by 1.
author: Cara C.

description: Average Thai food served to eager theatergoers while law students from Hastings across the street down their sorrows at the bar. The interior seems a little theatrical, like the decorator was cribbing notes from a Rainforest Cafe, but the bar has fresh lime juice and and extensive selection of gin and vodka should you want to put it to use in a proper gimlet instead of a whatever-tini.
author: Timothy O.

description: Great happy hour menu and good drinks.  Ate there for full dinner one night and thought it was just ok, but not spectacular.  But the happy-hour menu makes up for it!
author: Eric S.

description:
meh.  i dunno.

it was okay but nothing special.  ordered the satay appetizer and found the chicken a little too sweet and the peanut sauce somewhat lacking in peanut-y-ness.  

we shared a noodle entree (as we were having the late afternoon meal on a sunday) and it was just alright.  i love pad see ew (mm.. delicious flat wide noodles) and their version was, of course, edible and pretty tasty.   ::shrugs::  i've just had better.

we did see one of those whole crispy fried fish come out and i'll just say .. it LOOKED pretty impressive.

also to note: they got a lot of crowd from after-seeing-wicked.
convenient location.  decent food.  not a wow-er.  
give it a shot if you're in the neighborhood but i know i'll probably go elsewhere in my neverending search for delicious thai food.
author: Lily B.

description: My dining companion and I went there after a late Thursday visit to the nearby Asian Art Museum. The food was average/good; I has spring rolls and tofu and vegetables with peanut sauce, he had deep fried calamari and seafood clay pot. It's a bit higher priced than many Thai places with most entrees at $10.50 and up, given the unexceptional quality. I did like the enormous jungle mural, though.
author: Amy E.

description: So thrilled with Lalita's! A spacious, nicely decorated restaurant, we were promptly seated and greeted with a cucumber soup!!! Get the lunch special...spring rolls and fried yams as well as an entree for $7.95! On top of that, it was delicious!!!
author: Marlo G.

description: Interesting happy hour. Drinks are $3.50 (Draft and well) and Apps are $3.99. The Apps were decent (pot stickers, satay). However, the wings were odd to say the least. Really funky looking, but I guess they tasted good. Friendly and fast service helps, with plenty of seats at the bar and in the dining room...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Basil crispy chicken is the bomb here, served with half an egg roll and rice. I haven't been here for over half a year and when I recently return, I found they have drastically raised their lunch price. What they normally charged $8.99 is now $11.95. Significant jump considering the neighborhood and bad economy. It's hard for me to justify paying that much for an entree but I wouldn't mind coming back once in a while.
author: Jordan W.

description: I discovered this when looking for a restaurant to go to before a show at the Orpheum Theater.  There are very few viable options around there, but luckily, there is Lalita.  The food is a little pricy compared to other Thai restaurants, and the portions are nothing special, but the quality is excellent.  The service is great, and they'll make sure you're served in time to make your show.
author: Steve W.

description:
My first review - I just ate there an hour ago...

They are a reliable quick lunch option for me, with daily specials and running lunch specials of pad thai or yellow chicken curry.  Dinner isn't quite so good.  They have consistent quality, good prices and good service.  Its certainly not my favorite Thai, but what else is there to eat in the Tenderloin when you're sick of sandwiches?

I would give them a four if they still served that wonderful little soup with lunch, usually some variation of a tom yum, but I haven't seen it lately.
author: Josh E.

description: Happened to stumble across this place on New Year's Eve at 515pm. My party of 3 were seated quickly and everyone was very nice. Our waitress was very patient with us as we couldn't decide what to order. Maybe they were a little slow, but for us it was fine and we were able to walk the 1 block to the Orpheum with no problem. I'd definitely go back again as the food was good and reasonably priced. Beside restaurant seating, there is also room at the bar, and a bar seating area with additional bar tables and even a cozy couch area in the back. I now know where to go when I need food before seeing a show at the Orpheum, or am in the area. And they have a to-go menu too.
author: Janice O.

description: This place was always great if you were craving some thai food -- the service was always great, ambiance adorable and the food was decent.  The bar was also a nice local place to grab a drink after a rough day in the tenderloin ...
author: Roni R.

description: Found this place when I was looking for a quick drink and bite before Wicked. We sat in the bar. The Bartender Mimi (I think) was super sweet and bought my friend a birthday shot! We let her know that we had to hurry and she was on it! We ordered the calamari, shrimp rolls and chicken satu (sp?). It was all really good. I'm def going to find this place again for a quick bite!
author: CHRISTY M.

description: This place is close to my work, and i like to bring my friends here whenever they visit me at my work.  It's not overly crowded during lunch hours like other places in civic center area.  The food is not so bad.... just typical thai food.  I don't recommend the pan fried noodles here.  Lots of bland vegetables and too little sauce.  I highly recommend the curries.  Nice, quiet ambience.
author: Jessica N.

description: We picked up our tickets to "Wicked" at the Orpheum box office.  Asked the lady in the booth where to catch some supper while waiting for the show to start.  "There's a Thai restaurant over there just beyond the fountain (SF Civic Center)."  We expected maybe, average, but wow!  The best Thai food we have had yet!  Our appetizer was the "Salt & Pepper Beef Strips with Cashew Nuts and Crispy Basil."  A winner!  My wife Lise is a curry fan, and she said "It's as good as it gets!"  My Cashew Chicken was just as good.  This is a LIVE place, it was full, and there was a lively bar scene, to boot.  I don't see this place in any of my SF guide books, but we will be going back to Lalita next time we visit SF.  A very pleasant surprise.
author: William B.

description: Wow this place is great!  I love to find great places hidden in the Tenderloin.  They have good food, appetizers, and a awesome drink menu!  The portions are huge, I was super full and still had over half the meal left!  The decor is great too, they have a waterfall koi pond, beautiful and wall murals.  Service is good, and it is very close to the Orpheum if you are looking for a bite before a show.
author: Sunshine S.

description: After a few hours at the Asian Art Museum, I came upon this place. I looked at the menu, thinking "okay, either the food is going to be horrible or the food is going to be great and I'll have a good time."  Well, I order a cocktail...yum, very good. Then I order the Lemon Ginger chicken, again I was surprised that it was very tasty. I also like the waiter, who was very friendly and chatting up with the regulars. Not bad. I will come back.
author: Valerie D.

description: Really nice for the neighborhood. Great pre-theater fixed price meal of an appetizer, entree and dessert for $20. Maybe I just don't get around enough but this was the first place I saw spiked Thai iced tea so I had to try it, and it was great. The service was friendly and made sure we made it to the theater on time.
author: Melissa W.

description: Here is the place that serves Eye of the Hawk beer (see my review for Speakeasy Theater).  The food is nothing special, but the decor is nice, the bar is cool, and the bartender is a nice guy.
author: Mr. G.

description: Very aesthetically appealing once you walk in the door. The decor is great. Friendly service with the addition of awesome food is a great combination.  Before or after your meal, be sure to stop by the bar for a drink or two and to chat with the benign bartenders.
author: Milton W.

description: Their curried corn fritters and mango and sticky rice are the things dreams are made of.  The interior is lovely and the food is soothing.   No better combination!
author: P-Rock F.

description: We used to come here often for the basil chicken wings. The last time we ordered it, the dish was different and there were fewer pieces. Not sure if there was a change in the recipe but it wasn't as good. We were pretty disappointed. Otherwise it is a really nice space and the staff is friendly.
author: Lori E.

description: happy hour menu is the best. $4.50 for filling and delicious appetizers. My favorite is the salt&pepper beef strips. yummm! The owners are super friendly too.
author: Shayenne G.

description:
My wife and I took our 5 nieces and nephews there for dinner before going to Wicked at the Orpheum.

Wow! What an excellent dinner.  The best fried calamari.  The vegi dish with eggplant and tofu in red curry was delicious.

Everything was excellent.  Everybody was very happy.  An excellent restaurant to visit before a show at the Orpheum.
author: A S.

description: I prefer not coming here b/c location, but when I do, they always do a good job w/the food and stuff.  Not bad if you're in the area.
author: F K.

description: Awesome drinks (get the Crazy Thai Iced Tea) and appetizers (huge variety, all good). Their main courses are decent, but surprisingly bland. A beautiful oasis in a more desolate part of San Francisco. Overall, highly recommended for drinks and appetizers.
author: Joy C.

description: Good food, will come again..was very quiet for a sunday night dinner.
author: Aryan S.

description:
A group of friends and I were running late for a musical and needed a quick place to eat. We hit up the first place we found and we were all pleasantly surprised by Lalita's atmosphere. We told the waiter we had only 30 minutes to eat and literally 5 minutes after he left, our food was ready. It was ready before we even had our drinks!

The food was very good and decently priced. The service was amazing. We all agreed to come back to this place eventually. Hopefully with more than 30 mins to spare!

To top it all off, our waiter sprinted 3 blocks to hand me back my phone i had left behind! 

Must tries: Duck Fried Rice and Mojito
author: Milton T.

description: Overall great service and great food.  They have a really nice and comfortable atmosphere but don't play traditional Thai music.  They play jazz and top 40.  I've had the sea food dishes and they all have been very tasty.  Order the seafood in coconut sauce.  So delicious!  That and the corn fritters.  Definitely one of our favorite restaurants!
author: Jacob A.

description: This place owner/management has the WORST customer service ever! The waitress staff did not understand the questions nor could explain the menu very well during our horrible lunch experience. Decided to eat at this restaurant where we usually order the basil ground chicken from most Thai restaurants. We keep asking the waitress what lunch meal consist of the ground chicken, she could not understand our request so we ordered a chicken plate only to find out it was fried chicken strips in chili red sauce. The waitress brought a salad drenched in sweet salad dressing and 2 eggrolls first. Once the main course came, it was cold with dry chicken strips and uncooked green beans with a red chili sauce. We immediately contacted the manager and requested a different meal. We were told by managmenet we would not be able to order a different meal without paying for the first meal even thought we only ate the salad. After argueing with the manager for decent customer service and the fact we mentioned the waitress was unhelpful in advising the correct chicken we were rudelly told by the manager maybe they do not make that type of Thai chicken at their restaurant. The manager proceeding on by insisting we would probaly not like anything on the menu and if they make another meal then their restaurant would have to pay for the loss. We were appauled to say the least! We decided to leave the plate of food and pay for the plate we did have. Once we received the bill we were still billed for the order not eaten. After further disagreeing conversations the manager insisted we pay half for a twelve dollar meal to pay for the salad we had eaten. Although the customer service and experience was less than pleasant we paid for the salad and vowed to never return to this establishment again.
author: Evette A.

description: For me this joint is a diamond in the rough - literally.  Its location isn't the greatest or prettiest, but the food I found to be great.  Further the layout of the restaurant is a bit weird but the drinks and menu items is better than good.  Went on a quiet evening for dinner and ordered the bbq half chicken - and it was die for...I couldn't believe chicken could taste so good. Bravo!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Great place for lunch. The service can be a bit slow sometimes, but I have never been disappointed by the food. Everything is moderately priced, and the dishes come very well prepared. Very nice decor as well, especially for the neighborhood. :)

I have eaten at several Thai places in the local area and this is by far the tastiest of the bunch. I have had several of the offerings and they have all been great. Try the ribeye lunch special!
author: Sean M.

description: i LOVE thai food. Its hard to find a place that cooks yummy pad thai, and this place does! By the time i place my order at work, its ready by the time i walk over.. less than 10min. They have a cool bar and nice decor... BUT... when i went there for lunch with about 4 co-workers there were nats flying all over the place. they served us at different times, so peoples food got cold. my co-worker had to kill a nat with her bare hand... GROSS! it gets really crowded during lunch. but for me... i still order my pad thai... take-out. :)
author: MaryEllen F.

description: convenient and easy, but fairly unremarkable.  there is much better thai to be had in the bay!
author: Jill k.

description:
happy hour is one of my favorites. have been to lunch twice and wasn't blown away, but happy hour food/drink specials are a great after-work treat. bartenders are very nice.

they used to have eye of the hawk on tap, a rare and special occasion for the surprise buzz. not sure if they still have it, but it was great. ask for it.

great work-party place. had my going-away shindig here and it was oh-so appropriate!
author: Anne D.

description: It's pretty eh. Everything tastes the same--almost like fast food thai--too oily and the meat is not high quality. If you want thai go down to Lers Ros at Larkin and Ellis--it's much much better!
author: Lauren Q.

description: I went in for happy hour and left sad. The waitress was so rude and I got the feeling that she did not want me there. Writing bad reviews is not my thing but this place left me feeling icky. I just popped in because I had some minutes to kill before an appointment. The waitress/bartender raised her voice to me twice when I asked her about what cocktails she makes. She yelled at me when I asked her about the drink minimum. I think she may have thought I was from the neighborhood because I am not a young hipster/prepster or whatever. I just know that I am not ever going back there again. Don't judge people by looking at them, just try to provide good service. So lame.
author: Amber A.

description: decent thai food.. amazing decor.. it's a nice place to hang out from time to time.. despite the neighborhood..
author: Timothy W.

description: The rib-eye steak and rice lunch special rocks.
author: Travis K.

description: all things considered, a cornerstone for many yrs. in what would otherwise be total sketch-ville.  thanks Lalita for keeping the 'hood balanced with your warm inviting bar/restaurant and good food.
author: Ken H.

description: people, minnie's gone m.i.a. the one good thing at lalita's is gone. food there has always been just a-ok (i may have raved about some corn croquettes on the earlier post, but that was just written to humor my friends). otherwise, you know, it's thai food, whose imperial cuisine have mushroomed in every corner of every big city. you know that the beefstew you're eating only tastes good cuz 1. there's no other place that serves thai food within a 4-block vicinity 2. you're too drunk 3. you've been eating too much tu lan 4. it has so much sugar. oh, *sad face*--
author: benita b.

description: very disappointing. it's hard for thai food to be bad, but they managed... the pumpkin and chicken in the pumpkin and chicken curry were both very hard. the beef pad see ew was, well, eeew. it literally had no flavor. we had to pour the curry sauce over the beef dish for it to taste like anything at all. and the beef was chewy and gross. on top of it, service was slow.. it took over an hour, and they never even did bring us those chicken rolls we ordered...
author: erica r.
